292730: Djinn Illuminatus.author: EvilDarkVoid
292730: Djinn Illuminatus.text_parsed: This card doesn't actually give you infinite mana with a single ramp card like Seething Song. The reason for this is that you pay the Replicate cost when the spell is cast (meaning when you pay the mana cost and any additional costs for it, putting it on the stack) but you only get the effect of a card, in this case mana, when the card resolves (when all abilities and cards than can be cast or activated in response to it have been, assuming their controller chooses for them to, and everything above the card on the stack has resolved). It will give you a lot of mana, and having multiple cards like Seething Song in your hand will get you a lot more, probably enough to win the game, but not infinite unless you can find some way to keep casting your ramp spells for less mana than you're getting out of replicating them.
292730: Djinn Illuminatus.text_posted: This card doesn't actually give you infinite mana with a single ramp card like [autocard]Seething Song[/autocard]. The reason for this is that you pay the Replicate cost when the spell is cast (meaning when you pay the mana cost and any additional costs for it, putting it on the stack) but you only get the effect of a card, in this case mana, when the card resolves (when all abilities and cards than can be cast or activated in response to it have been, assuming their controller chooses for them to, and everything above the card on the stack has resolved).  It will give you a lot of mana, and having multiple cards like[autocard] Seething Song[/autocard] in your hand will get you a lot more, probably enough to win the game, but not infinite unless you can find some way to keep casting your ramp spells for less mana than you're getting out of replicating them.

292730: Djinn Illuminatus.author: Grakling
292730: Djinn Illuminatus.text_parsed: To all that are wondering about the infinite mana conundrum with mana ramping spells and this - you can't do it off one casting of the card. Replicate costs have to be made up front as you cast the spell (read the reminder text). You might be able to rig up an infinite combo off it with a spell that you can buyback, or something akin to that, but most of those types of combo don't need replicate to take off.

292730: Djinn Illuminatus.author: car2n
292730: Djinn Illuminatus.text_parsed:
Let's say you have 3 D.I. in play. you spend 5 red mana, one to play Shock, and 4 to pay the replicate cost four times.
Since the wording in the reminder text says "When you cast it , copy it for each time you payed the replicate cost."
If you payed the replicate cost 4 times, do each Djinn include its "copy it for each time you payed the replicate cost" clause, thus multiplying the effect?

Would it be 1 shock, plus 4 replicated, for a total of 5 Shocks?

Or 4 replicate cost payments times the number of D.I's in play, plus the 1 origional; for (4 replicates)x(3 Djinn Illuminatis)+(1 origional copy) for a total of 13 Shocks?

The answer is NO. Here's why:

"702.53b If a spell has multiple instances of replicate, each is paid separately and triggers based on the payments made for it, not any other instance of replicate. "

292735: Izzet Guildmage.text_parsed:
But dat Epic Experiment and Melek combo tho.

@Zoah
Slight problem, his ability has to be cast while the spell(such as Rite of Flame) is on the stack, i.e. before it resolves, i.e. before the {R}{R} goes to your mana pool.
So you can copy Rite of Flame as many times as you have mana for, but there is unfortunately no infinite combo to be found here. If you have multiples, then you can at least double your mana more than once.

292737: Nivix, Aerie of the Firemind.text_parsed:
This card was a shoo-in for flavor reasons, but alas, it still sucks.
To put this in perspective, you're effectively paying just to exile the top card of your library - and you still have to pay its mana cost if you want to play it. And you're limited to this turn, otherwise it vanishes forever. Looks like Niv-Mizzet put more time into making it look pretty than into making it actually work.

292738: Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind.author: RowanKeltizar
292738: Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind.text_parsed:
While the new art is a far cry from the old, I still like it. It looks great in foil. I don't know why they omitted flavor text this time since there's plenty of space for it. I own and play with both versions.

Where Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind truly shines is as a Commander. Fill your deck with cards like Timetwister, Wheel of Fortune, Windfall, and Winds of Change and you will be doing a lot of damage for very little mana. And in Thought Reflection or Consecrated Sphinx and you have a ridiculous amount of draw and damage.

My personal favorite combo with Niv is Mindmoil + Dream Halls or Omniscience. You can cycle your hand indefinitely for free resulting in near infinite damage from Niv.

Besides Curiosity you can use Ophidian Eye, Tandem Lookout, and Mind Over Matter for the infinite loop.

292739: Pyromatics.author: manaderp
292739: Pyromatics.text_parsed:
@Lord_of_Gelectrodes: This doesn't have that much synergy with heroic creatures such as Anax and Cymede. Copying a spell isn't casting it. Now, some things can copy spell cards - eg. cipher, the stick - and there the copy is being created elsewhere, usually from exile, so it needs to be cast. Here, the copy's created on the stack, so it doesn't need to be cast to get on the stack. But the easy way to tell: Does the effect say "cast"? If so, you're casting, and it'll trigger heroic. If not, you're not, and it won't. (See the last ruling on Anax and Cymede.)

@Krysto: No. Goblin Electromaner lowers the cost paid to cast a spell. Replicate is a triggered ability that lets you pay a cost to copy a spell. Entirely different. (It'd have been great flavor-wise if he'd help... Not so much balance-wise though.)
292739: Pyromatics.text_posted:
@Lord_of_Gelectrodes: This doesn't have that much synergy with heroic creatures such as [autocard]Anax and Cymede[/autocard]. Copying a spell isn't casting it. Now, some things can copy spell [i]cards[/i] - eg. [autocard multiverseid="369021"]cipher[/autocard], the stick - and there the copy is being created elsewhere, usually from exile, so it needs to be cast. Here, the copy's created on the stack, so it doesn't need to be cast to get on the stack. But the easy way to tell: Does the effect say "cast"? If so, you're casting, and it'll trigger heroic. If not, you're not, and it won't. (See the last ruling on Anax and Cymede.)

292740: Train of Thought.author: NW9k
292740: Train of Thought.text_parsed: I think this card has its upsides and downsides. Upside is the fact that you can replicate as much as you can afford to, and so get as much card advantage as you can OR you can spend just a bit of mana for a card. Downside, is that if you are using other instant speed card draw, they are usually more efficient. Blue Sun's Zenith requires 4 mana for 1 card, which is awful in comparison, but recycles itself, and for 6 mana you get three cards, while recycling. 7 mana makes it much better than Opportunity since Blue Sun's recycles, and I just never liked Oppurtunity(I think it's too high cost to be an instant, even if it is really good card advantage).

292748: Call to Heel.author: Ferlord
292748: Call to Heel.text_parsed:
Go away, Blizzardspectre.

This is... a weird card to play. I think I speak for many when I say it's worse than unsummon. It either makes you weary of playing it on your opponent's creature, or regrettable when you've wasted 2 mana returning a creature to your hand for 1 card.

Usually, you'd return your own creature to your hand to either protect it or use it to activate the Enter the Battlefield effect again.

292751: Brainstorm.author: EGarrett01
292751: Brainstorm.text_parsed:
This card has quietly become one of the absolute best in the history of Magic.

It was strong library manipulation before combo. It was strong library manipulation and a combo deck enabler before it worked like BUTTER with the sac-lands, it was strong library manipulation, a combo deck enabler AND worked like butter with sac-lands before it synergized with Countertop. It was library manipulation, a combo deck enabler, worked like butter with sac lands AND synergized with Countertop BEFORE IT BECAME A NEARLY BROKEN BEAST-MACHINE WITH MIRACLE.

Now, to be honest, it might have passed counterspell as the most staple blue card in the history of the game. And is clearly already the most played.

All for a little Ice Age common. Amazing.

292751: Brainstorm.author: SevesDariku
292751: Brainstorm.text_parsed:
This, Ponder and Preordain are compared a lot.

While I think Preordain is better in more decks, Brainstorm here goes from being a solid card, to being holy-crap-amazing in the right deck, because there are two important things it does that Ponder and Preordain don't.

First, it draws three cards. Sure, you put two back, but blue has plenty of reasons to want the words "draw 3 cards" to be on something. Thought Reflection and Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind are just two.

Second, it puts cards from your hand on the top of the deck. This is fantastic with any Miracle card, or with something like Melek.

So basically, out of Brainstorm, Ponder and Preordain, the three 'ancestral-lite' cards... This card is really the only one you could ever expect to provide more use than the original Ancestral Recall.

Easy 5/5

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: Aquillion
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
It's an awesome card, both powerful and fun, but people do sometimes overrate it. Its big weakness is that you have to imprint something on it out of your hand, which leads to two more weaknesses in turn:

1. It's very vulnerable to removal. If it gets naturalized the moment it hits play, that's an automatic -1. (You can sometimes avoid this by using it immediately to at least get the benefit of the imprinted card once, but many popular imprints aren't useful like that.)

2. You need to have the other card ready to imprint on it, or it's just deadweight in your hand. This is the real reason you never really saw it dominating at tournaments -- isochron scepter is unbelievably powerful when it works, but it's not enough to just have an idea for a strong imprint on it. To really use it well, you need a deck that naturally contains a large number of 2-mana instants and is still strong even if it takes you a long time to draw your scepters. There aren't very many decks like that.

(Don't get me wrong, it's still one of the strongest artifacts ever printed. But it's not completely gamebreaking the way it looks at first -- or the way it sometimes feels when you do manage to get it out with a really strong spell on it.)

2.  You need to have the other card ready to imprint on it, or it's just deadweight in your hand.  This is the real reason you never really saw it dominating at tournaments -- isochron scepter is unbelievably powerful when it works, but it's not enough to just have an idea for a strong imprint on it.  To really use it well, you need a deck that [i]naturally[/i] contains a large number of 2-mana instants and is still strong even if it takes you a long time to draw your scepters.  There aren't very many decks like that.

(Don't get me wrong, it's still one of the strongest artifacts ever printed.  But it's not completely gamebreaking the way it looks at first -- or the way it sometimes feels when you do manage to get it out with a really strong spell on it.)

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: Tower_Mazer
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
Questions how does this work with split cards and fuse splits?

1st, split cards with fuse I can't find a ruling. I know on split cards you can cast only 1 side without paying it's mana cost. I'm only assuming you can't fuse the spells because it would be like paying a kicker or similar?
Answer I found - If youâre casting a split card with fuse from any zone other than your hand, you canât cast both halves. Youâll only be able to cast one half or the other.

2nd, I need confirmation on this ruling: "If the copied card is a split card, you may choose to cast either side of the split card, but not both. The split cards Fire/Ice, Illusion/Reality, Night/Day, Stand/Deliver, and Wax/Wane all have at least one side with converted mana cost 2 or less."

To me you can choose what side you are casting upon activation not that you are only coping one side and can only cast that side since it doesn't say copy only cast in the ruling. I have a judge telling me I can only copy 1 side. I disagree considering this is a game on manipulating text to your advantage.

3rd, since you are not paying the cmc of the exiled spell, can play the say 3 casting cost side of Far/Away? Far meets the needs of the cmc 2 or less requirement as stated in the above quoted ruling.

Thanks

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: adrian.malacoda
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
@Toquinha1977: You can only Cipher the spell card itself, not a copy, as the rules for Cipher specifically state that you may exile "this spell card". A spell cast through Isochron Scepter (or, for that matter, through Cipher itself) is not a card, so you cannot Cipher it.

@HoboColin: "Alternative cost" means something like Force of Will where you do something else instead of pay its usual cost. You can't do that with scepter. "Additional cost" is something like Fling where you have to do something else in addition to its usual cost. You CAN put Fling on this but you'd have to sac a creature every time you use it. Kicker is an optional additional cost. You are never forced to pay the Kicker, but you have the option to. If you choose to Kick the spell then you have to pay the kicker cost.

@Tower_Mazer: First, you can't use Fuse with Isochron Scepter. Fuse is an alternative cost, like buyback. Second, in every case where you imprint a split card onto Scepter, you may only cast one side of it. The imprint ability calls for an "instant card with CMC 2 or less." The way mana cost works with split cards is tricky - technically speaking, the CMC of Far/Away is 2 and 3 at the same time (not 5). Therefore, it meets the criteria for imprint. The activated ability of Scepter always costs {2}, regardless of the CMC of the card you are casting. The activated ability of Scepter doesn't check the CMC of the spell you are casting, so you are indeed free to cast Away off the Scepter for {2}.

@Everyone suggesting sorceries for use with Isochron Scepter: It works with instants only.

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: tavaritz
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
A little game evolution fact. Check for example Throne of Bone's wording between 5th edition and 6th. Then check all versions of this.

Now try to find all articles from net that tells you why "cast" was bad word and was changed to "play" and then why "play" was bad word and was changed back to "cast".

I'm getting the feeling that Wizards no longer know what they are doing.

P.S. This is uncommon in Mirrodin, which means that every booster pack has certain probabilty to contain this, the probability being smaller than for any given rare but larger than for any given common in Mirrodin. But now, if you buy FTV: Relics or DD: Izzet vs. Golgari you get this card automatically, so you cannot talk about any probability based rarity of it in those sets at all.

In fact the FTV: Relics version is as rare as any other card in FTV: Relics and the DD: Izzet vs. Golgari version is as rare as most of the other cards in that set, the exception being that there is nine cards (Elves of Deep Shadow, Golgari Rot Farm, Golgari Rotwurm, Izzet Boilerworks, Kiln Fiend, Putrefy, Pyromatics, Shrewd Hatchling and Wee Dragonauts) that are twice as likely to exist as DD: Izzet vs. Golgari versions, as one gets two of them in every set.

P.P.S. Of course the basic lands were left out in all the previous.

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: casualhorror
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
Definitely a hilarious sideboard card on the cheap. Feels like siding into the Gifts Package but it is a little worse than that.
It eats removal like all hungry little artifacts do, with Abrupt Decay feeling especially bad and it sometimes doesn't get paired with the right instant in your deck to lock your opponent completely. But then there are games where you have imprinted something like Lightning Bolt or even better Lightning Helix and they don't have a creature with toughness more than 3. The best is win you don't side it in and they keep their blanked artifact removal.
But yeah, not going to win a Modern tournament any time soon. If everyone's seven artifact destruction slots got used better elsewhere (which would require Arcbound Ravager being banned) maybe it'd be pretty nice. Until then the downsides of getting it answered and the fact everyone has to have an answer in sideboard to play Modern is just too backbreaking for our little Isochron.

292752: Isochron Scepter.author: Tempted_Johnny
292752: Isochron Scepter.text_parsed:
@ Aquillion: Thank you. Your comment is spot-on!

In Modern format, you'd have a lot to contend with if you're hoping to profit from Scepter. First, you need both Scepter and a desirable card to imprint in hand, making it especially weak to Thoughtseize and Inquisition of Kozilek.

Then, you should avoid being two-for-oned. Abrupt Decay, Maelstrom Pulse, Qasali Pridemage, Beast Within, and Karn Liberated are some obstacles in this category.

That being said, there are a couple rules to follow when playing scepter:

1. Treat Isochron Scepter as if it costs , not (Ignore this rule pre-sideboarding against straight aggro).

2. Cantrips are a must. Not only do they help prevent Scepter from being dead by keeping a fuller hand, but they're among the best cards to imprint. Manamorphose and Remand are probably the best main-board options. Shadow of Doubt and Squelch are great sideboard options.

292758: Dissipate.author: atemu1234
292758: Dissipate.text_parsed:
@kasaiaisu Yes, counterspell is strictly better than cancel. People who disagree need to get off of gatherer. That is the poster-child for strictly better. Kind of like shock v lightning bolt.
Strictly better refers to a card that fulfills one (or both) of the following parameters.
A) It does the same thing for less mana. (this is situation 1. Counterspell v. Cancel.)
B) It does the same thing +something that is considered good in almost all situations, not taking into account an opponent's actions. (IE, cantrip. No, just because you may have no cards in your library does not make cantrip a bad thing overall)
Examples that look like it but aren't:
Vapor Snag v. Unsummon.
Why it looks like it: Oh hey, my opponent loses one life if I return his creature!
Why it isn't: Your opponent's creatures are only one use for a card like unsummon. You can return your own creature to cast it again and reap the benefits of, say, a enter the battlefield ability.

292758: Dissipate.author: DarthParallax
292758: Dissipate.text_parsed:
How to define ''strictly'' better?

I think it should be: "If in 100% of Tier 1 Decks, and 90% of logical Casual Decks, you'd rather have a particular card for the same basic use over a particular other card, then it's strictly better".

Force of Will is strictly better than both Counterspell and Cancel and TO HELL with your corner cases where you're trying to exploit interesting "features". That's Johnny-Thinking. Johnny-Thinking DOES have its place in Magic, but "Strictly Better" is as SPIKE as it gets. Johnny and Spike are SOMETIMES friends but this is The Line:

"Will it make me win Better? Yes? It's strictly better.

No? Then what will make me win Better?"-- Spike

"Well you can build all kinds of decks that all do different kinds of things and they'd each want different types of specialized tools?"-- Johnny

"Listen you. I want to execute a Plan of some kind sure, but the Best Plans are simple. If more than three things need to go right for you, your plan sucks because banking on the opponent being stupid and letting you do what you want is dumb. I want the one-liner rules text cards, please, except when they make my spells faster and more inevitable, or give me cold hard math dominance, over resources. Luck is a resource which is why I play Fetch Lands. Where victory chances are continuously more and more conditional for my opponent until they don't have any REAL odds of winning. I want to have My Plan, I want Disrupt their Plan, and I want to do it Fast, by Surprise if I can or with Brute Force if I have to. The CONDITIONS under which your cards are better at 'Adding up to your Own Plan' create an Unwieldy Weapon that would never be useable in an actual combat situation. Johnny, what you make up for in Abnormally Large and Creative Brains (RAVENCLAW!), you lack in Intent to KILL." --Spike (SLYTHERIN!)

^This is a very EXTREME portrait of Spike, a Spike who for the purposes of argument refuses to use any other mindset BUT Spike. To ACHIEVE the Kill you Intend, you usually need to consult Timmy on good P/T mana ratios and Vorthos is invaluable in psych-reading your opponents: "Learn how they think. If you can tell what makes sense to them, I can tell you how to surprise them. I can tell you what their Flavor is and teach you how to be Unflavorful to them." (Spike-Vorthos is a Jerk XD)

Johnny-Vorthos can ALWAYS invent a new Weird Idea and try something Impertinently Clever....but Spike doesn't care and that doesn't change whether a card is Strictly Better or Not UNTIL you've scored a Real Kill with it. There. That's basically it. Strictly Better cards, are Cards that Achieve Kills or work in cohesion with other cards to Create a Kill. Kills are judged by their size, picking on someone's Axelrod Gunnarson Commander Deck isn't that big a Kill, taking out the other 7 in a Standard (or any format) GP Top 8 is a Big Kill.

Free Counterspell tacked onto what could potentially be an Opportunity, though your floor is pretty low. I guess this could really shine in Commander, as you're most likely to see truly large spells in that format, especially from people who are taking advantage of mana ramp alongside multicasting Prossh. That deck alone loves to cast him at 10, 12, or sometimes even 20 mana, and getting rid of something that dangerous coupled with drawing that many cards in EDH is, well, quite impressive.

It could be awesome, but I guess the "creature" clause is what really dumps this card in the gutter.

292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.author: wheeledgoat
292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.text_parsed:
The 2nd ruling is crap!

"If the targeted creature or player is an illegal target by the time the ability resolves, the ability is countered. You won't put a charge counter on Sphinx-Bone Wand and it won't deal damage."

The card clearly states that you first put a charge counter upon casting a spell, and then it deals damage. If the target's gone, then fine - it does no damage, but the charge counter should still be added! (IMHO).
292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.text_posted:
The 2nd ruling is crap!

"[i]If the targeted creature or player is an illegal target by the time the ability resolves, the ability is countered. You won't put a charge counter on Sphinx-Bone Wand and it won't deal damage.[/i]"

The card clearly states that you first put a charge counter upon casting a spell, and then it deals damage.  If the target's gone, then fine - it does no damage, but the charge counter should still be added!  (IMHO).

292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.author: MithosFall
292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.text_parsed: @wheeledgoat: Any spells and single abilities (Sphinx-Bone Wand only has one ability) that has the word "target" in it requires all of its targets to be legal when being put onto the stack and at least one target to be legal when it resolves.  It's the only way that makes sense to R&D and there would be TONS of problems if things were different.
292760: Sphinx-Bone Wand.text_posted: @wheeledgoat: Any spells and single abilities (Sphinx-Bone Wand only has one ability) that has the word "target" in it requires all of its targets to be legal when being put onto the stack and at least one target to be legal when it resolves.  It's the only way that makes sense to R&D and there would be TONS of problems if things were different.

292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.author: Totema
292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.text_parsed: Even his first ability makes him good: for 2 instead of , he's a +2/+1 Lhurgoyf with very relevant tribes. His second ability feeds himself and hurts an opponent at the same time. And his third makes it hard for him to stay off the battlefield. Elves frequently don't mind lands hitting the grave, so it's definitely a neat possibility for elf tribal EDH. I can see a few games ending suddenly on a sacrificed Heedless One or Jagged-Scar Archers.

292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.author: General_Naga
292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.text_parsed:
This guy is a straight-up HOUSE. As I write this, he's been on sale for all of three days, and I've seen him as an EDH General, a member of the 99, and a few times in 60 card decks. Each time he touches down, there's a collective gasp from all the other players, and everyone starts trying to figure out how to kill him. Not only is he a bigger Boneyard Wurm, itself a fearsome beater in the right deck, but he also has the ability to sac your Boneyard Wurms, Lhurgoyfs, and Mortivores for massive life loss all around. Combo that with the fact that HE JUST WONT STAY DEAD, especially when running Life from the Loam to recur your sacced swamps and forests.

He is far more fearsome than he appears at first glance, and even at first glance people start quaking in their boots.

That is EXACTLY what a legendary creature and a mythic rare should be, powerful enough to inspire fear in your opponents.

5/5

292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.author: Goatllama
292771: Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord.text_parsed:
I really wish he could sac himself to his ability. He's a lich, so he shouldn't fear death, and his +1/+1 for each gravecreature would provide such nice synergy. Then of course just sac some lands and he's reborn. I feel like that's what would really push him over into mythic territory. As is, he's still fairly powerful, just not as much as he could be if he were practicing the true tenets of Golgari: all is fertilizer. All will be one eventually, anyways.

Edit: That said, after playing him in standard 'Dredge,' the second ability can be demned powerful, and it's exactly what G/B needs to get through straight to the life, something it isn't always able to do. I still wish he could sac himself, but I do have more respect for him now.

I dislike how this costs life to cast when Arbor Elf, Avacryn's Pilgrim, and Llanowar Elf have no such cost attached to them. 292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.author: Mode
292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.text_parsed:
I know it's an elf and not a minotaur,
but at first glance at this card, i always see a bull's head staring at me:
The elf's hat looks like the bull's forehead with dark fur and his face looks like the bull's snout - the eyes are the nostrils and the chin looks like the lower lip. Additionally the hat has slight 'notches' below the horns, which make it look like there are the bull's eye sockets.

So when i look at Justin Sweet's art of Elves of Deep Shadow,
i look at it at a skinny minotaur shaman that might as well be "Minotaur Reaper of Deep Shadow".

I can't possibly be the only one, right?

292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.author: Blackworm_Bloodworm
292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.text_parsed:
@Everlastingwords: It has a drawback to generate mana because black is an enemy color to green, and it wouldn't make sense for a card to produce pure black mana without some kind of flavorful drawback. Producing mana is green's specialty, not black's.

Birds of Paradise are bit different because they symbolize green's rainbow ramp efficiency and aptitude with mana in general, and Noble Hierarch... well, Hierarch is just an overpowered card.
It's at least Bant, but it would've made more sense for Naya to get the undercosted one instead of Druid of the Anima, since green is Naya's primary color.

I'd say we're due a producing Llanowar Elf-type creature though, what with Avacyn's Pilgrim and all

292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.author: GordonFreechmen
292942: Elves of Deep Shadow.text_parsed:
The reason it is dumb that it costs life is because Green can produce black mana without life loss. Look at Birds of Paradise. I make black mana with no downside. Same for Sylvan Caryatid, and Utopia Sprawl, and verdant Haven. Sure none of those are elves, but they all produce black mana, and two of the ones I mentioned do so for the cost of 1 mana to play. Why should it cost life to tap for black mana? Just because black is an enemy color. Well I get that it is, but none the less other green cards let you do it without life loss. And look at Noble Heirarch, taps for blue. An enemy color. Yet no life loss. So what is the reason it costs life just because it's black and black is all about life loss? So we gimp them and make an effect which wouldn't cost life; cost life just because it is black? That just seems silly.

Now don't get me wrong it's still a good card, I just really don't think it should require life loss.

292952: Golgari Signet.author: Wurmcaller
292952: Golgari Signet.text_parsed:
Big Golgari fan flavor-wise and mechanic-wise. The whole idea of a guild that focuses on Life and Death is pretty cool. Even though the guild has the iconic black selfishness, they manage to still move forward in one direction for the good of nature and the natural order. Plus plant zombies are pretty awesome.

Although I like dredge as a mechanic more than salvage, I fully understand them wanting to change the mechanic to something less "combo-able". Dredge often fed itself and became unstoppable once you had a few cards you could repeatedly pull from the grave. I just wish it didn't require exiling cards from the graveyard, because it weakens Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord, as well as Golgari Reanimator decks. Still excited to play Golgari in RtR though.

338388: Putrid Leech.author: blurrymadness
338388: Putrid Leech.text_parsed:
One of the most well designed and perfect creatures in magic. It's color-pie true, it's very powerful, it's in it's shard, it's flavorful, and it's beautiful.

Powerful because it:
-trades with some 4 and 5 drops
-only eats life when you need it to
-is a fast clock
-is only a 2 drop

Flavorful because it sucks health (sacrifice for power = B, sucking health for pump makes sense for the creature)

In the color pie because:
-nasty leech fits GB
-B sacrifice for power
-G above the curve creature; wins combats like a beast
-G (and somewhat B) because it's a pump effect

In the shard out side of that?
-Notice how it's R,G, and B in it's color scheme: Meant for jund, even in the artwork
-It's pure aggression

How would this card work with Flayer of the Hatebound? The issue that we where discussing was this:

2. Plays Twilight's Call, all creatures returned to the battlefield including Flayer of the Hatebound.

-The argument against it was, since all creatures entered simultaneously, Flayer's ability would only work for himself because he was not out before any of the other creatures entered.

Who is right?

338400: Boneyard Wurm.author: Antsache
338400: Boneyard Wurm.text_parsed:
@EEAGLESFFL20
As with all similar */* creatures, this is a static ability that constantly checks graveyards. If more creatures enter the graveyard (whether through death or discard), it gets stronger. Likewise, if something gets pulled out of a graveyard, it will get weaker. You can even kill one of these if you manage to eliminate all creatures from all graveyards (Tormod's Crypt if there's none in your 'yard, or something similar).
338400: Boneyard Wurm.text_posted:
@EEAGLESFFL20
As with all similar */* creatures, this is a static ability that constantly checks graveyards.  If more creatures enter the graveyard (whether through death or discard), it gets stronger.  Likewise, if something gets pulled out of a graveyard, it will get weaker. 338402: Reassembling Skeleton.author: UnusuallyShifty
338402: Reassembling Skeleton.text_parsed:
Ah, the Reassembling Skeleton. *Fistbump* My bro. My next favourite creature after Thrun.

I've been using this little dude as fuel for a sort of pauper's legacy Stax deck while I work on getting some Crucible of Worlds put together. He costs a little mana to wire back together every turn after loading up the Smokestack, so I put in a Black Market and some Blood Artists to cash out on all the dead creatures, with Necropotence and Skullclamp (I'm not a proud man...) for card draw. Victory comes from a massive Exsanguinate fuelled by 10-15 extra {B} from the Black Market. Extra leverage comes from using ol' Skelly with Ashnod's Altar and a Black Market/Blood Artist/Grave Pact, or a Pawn of Ulamog for mana loading and extra sacrifice victims.

There's all sorts of other crazy stuff you can do with a renewable sacrifice creature, and the Reassembling Skeleton is the most versatile among them. His only downside is that he comes back into play tapped, unlike the Nether Traitor or Bloodghast, neither of which can block, but you can just reassemble him at the end of your opponent's turn if you've got the mana left.

He's not necessarily good for every deck, but I've used Demonic Tutors for him. If that's not an endorsement I don't know what is. 4/5

I liked this card a lot when I first saw it. But what ends up happening is that you don't want to play it until they drop a flyer. In this sense sometimes its better to maindeck deadly recluse to fill this role.

Hes just sticking up your hand and leaving you to guess if they have a flyer or not. If they do and you drop it too early, then they get out their big flyer. If they don't then hes just waiting for no reason.

Still, this does make a nice sideboard card.

"You ate yourself?"
"Uh-huh."
"That's impossible."
"No it isn't."
"It would make you smaller."
"I got bigger."
"How does that work?"
"Magic."

338406: Golgari Grave-Troll.author: Damncat
338406: Golgari Grave-Troll.text_parsed:
I got 3 of these in my B/G/U self-mill deck, and I discovered an awesome combo:
Get this guy into your graveyard (somehow), and have at least one creature that has "T: Draw a card, discard a card", like merfolk looter or thought courier. Activate their ability, and return Golgari Grave-Troll to your hand instead of drawing a card. Then mill 6 cards, and discard Golgari Grave-Troll.
This basically changes the afore-mentioned card texts to "T: Mill 6 cards"... Which can be EXTREMELY effective!
5/5!
338406: Golgari Grave-Troll.text_posted:

338408: Sadistic Hypnotist.author: Werewolf-
338408: Sadistic Hypnotist.text_parsed:
It always pains me when they bring back oldies like this guy and people don't recognize them. It makes me feel old.

Here's your history lesson--the Hypnotist was first printed back in 2001, back during Odyssey block. A big theme in that block was the Cabal, a black-aligned organization led by the Cabal Patriarch and known for the gambling ring and pit fights it hosted (see Cabal Pit). People who worked for the cabal were called minions...like Cabal Inquisitor, Chainer, Dementia Master, Braids, Cabal Minion, and this guy.

His flavor text and creature type are both completely appropriate once you understand where he comes from.
338408: Sadistic Hypnotist.text_posted:
It always pains me when they bring back oldies like this guy and people don't recognize them. It makes me feel old.

338408: Sadistic Hypnotist.author: SevesDariku
338408: Sadistic Hypnotist.text_parsed:
I recently decided to swap him in for another card in my Savra, Queen of the Golgari deck, and boy does he work beautifully...

Of my sac engines in that deck (I have 8 of them, not counting ones that cost mana, tapping, or otherwise can't be done infinitely for free) most of them really just exist to enable sacrifices, and have a bonus as a nice extra, but this guy? The first time I played him, I sac'ed my entire field minus him and Savra, wiped all my opponent's creatures, and cleared all if their hands (I had to sacrifice about 8 creatures, but that's what that deck does best). I was greeted with a group-scoop at that point.

Oh good times

338409: Life from the Loam.author: j_mindfingerpainter
338409: Life from the Loam.text_parsed:
@ TimmyForever:

That's not the only use for this card. But I'll tell you how many lands go in your graveyard.

In Modern, every deck with two or more colors has fetchlands. ~ 4 at least. And then there are decks with Knight of the Reliquary. And then you play against decks with Molten Rain or decks that splash Stone Rain. Then there are a lot of decks that run Fulminator Mage. And then there's the first and ultimate abilities of Liliana of the Veil. Both of those usually put lands in your graveyard. Then there's Flagstones of Trokair, which thins your stuff on purpose. And if you're playing a Dredge or even self-mill deck, even if this gets milled, you can get more lands if you're short on mana.

And then there's just the Dredge part of it...

338409: Life from the Loam.author: blurrymadness
338409: Life from the Loam.text_parsed:
Also good for the old Depletion Lands! Those will die eventually while giving you temporary ramp. You occasionally get screwed with them if the game goes on to long and you miss land drops. This helps keep your deck solid next to HIckory woodlot and whatever other colors you're using.

As mentioned, absolutely boss next to cycling lands.
Also very good next to man-lands for recurrable blockers. Stall that game til you can end it :)


@Timmy
Aside from:
Fetchlands
Cycling Lands (2 cycles of those have been printed btw)
Manlands and Zoetic Cavern
Depletion Lands
Lands that sac for additional mana
Opponents using Wasteland

The fact the card has *dredge* right on it; means probably 1-2 lands per turn going to the grave. Having this in your starting hand in a non-abusive dredge deck = perfect mana-drops the rest of the game. with ~1 casting. Which is amazing.

This also works in land's edge combos, over-filled hands, destroy-land decks, raze &boom//bust, discard decks, Looting effects, Windfall or Wheel of Fortune effects, burning inquiry, the list goes on and on.

If you can't figure out how to use this card you're not using your imagination. You can put it in decks that, without gravehate, are virtually unstoppable because nothing screws up your mana curve while the effects for your opponent are terrible.

Again, notice how it's *land*, not "basic land", which is huge!!!

338411: Street Spasm.author: StreamHopper
338411: Street Spasm.text_parsed:
I didn't like the overload cost on this card when I first saw it. It was one of the first cards spoiled for Return to Ravnica, and I looked on this card (and the overload mechanic) with disdain. I labeled the card as pack-filler at best, and the overload mechanic as Kicker with a new name.

Then I, in tandem with my friend, purchased the Izzet vs Golgari duel decks the day after their release.

After a few uses of the card, I came to love running into it. At instant speed, this card is ready to hit the table any time you need it to, which is a huge advantage. I was already aware that you didn't have to pay the overload cost. However, it was the mechanic that made this card different from Heat Ray, which made me want more from it.

I realized that it was actually better than Heat Ray in almost every case, which is a card I never complained about (I actually drafted it as often as I could). Then, after warring with the Golgari swarm, I saw the appeal of the overload cost. It's meant to deal with token swarm, not bigger creatures! In fact, later, a card was spoiled called, Mizzium Mortars, which is an entirely different card made to be the kind of board-wipe I was looking for out of this card.

To put it simply, you won't love/fear this card until your opponent plays the "Life" part of Life//Death, and prepares to swing for game. You'll laugh maniacally like a true Izzet for several seconds before wiping them clean of land and creatures.

This card is perfectly costed and perfectly balanced coexisting with Mizzium Mortars. I basically had my faith in WotC restored, and my faith in my guild restored.

I <3 the Izzet, and I hope their experiments & explosions rock standard for the many months to come.

To put it simply, you won't love/fear this card until your opponent plays the "Life" part of [autocard]Life//Death[/autocard], and prepares to swing for game. You'll laugh maniacally like a true Izzet for several seconds before wiping them clean of land and creatures. 

This card is perfectly costed and perfectly balanced coexisting with Mizzium Mortars. I basically had my faith in WotC restored, and my faith in my guild restored.

I <3 the Izzet, and I hope their experiments & explosions rock standard for the many months to come.

338411: Street Spasm.author: Casimir_the_Great
338411: Street Spasm.text_parsed:
Yes DarthParallax, us Izzet are quite the Johnnies!

Overload does have the potential to be just a sideline gimmick or a Kicker reprint, but I think the WotC guys nailed it when they were making the bigger cost. However, take a second look at it: There's no target, so Shroud and Hexproof don't matter; It doesn't matter whether you hit two or twenty targets (unlike Replicate); and you still have the option to only hit a single creature! Combine this ability with original Izzet cards to get the best of both: Suddenly Weapon Surge gives all your creatures +4/+0 and First Strike thanks to Djinn Illuminatus (throw in a couple of Goblin Electromancers while the Djinn's out to really make things spin out of control!), a single Izzet Charm can be replicated and then wipe out almost anyone you want with Tibor and Lumia, lump Melek, Izzet Paragon with a Replicate or Overload card...Izzet has lots of flexibility and power, and is by far the best guild IMO.

338414: Goblin Electromancer.author: adrian.malacoda
338414: Goblin Electromancer.text_parsed:
See Return to Ravnica FAQ: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/faq/rtr

YES this works with Overload (alternate cost), just like it would with flashback, or miracle.
YES this works with Replicate (additional cost) but NOT in the way you would expect. Replicate, like Kicker, Buyback, and Entwine, is an additional cost added on top of the normal cost. This means that no matter how many times you Replicate a spell, Electromancer only shaves off the total cost. This seems meaningless at first glance, because it's only a discount of , but multiple Electromancers stack.

Say for example you control two Electromancers and cast Pyromatics, Replicating it once. The cost increase of Replicate is applied first, resulting in a cost of - you are not casting two spells for each, you are casting the one spell for . The Electromancer's ability kicks in afterwards, reducing it by (one for each Electromancer) meaning you pay a total of for your replicated Pyromatics.

Trinisphere complicates things further - it's applied even after the Electromancer's ability. In this hypothetical example, a Trinisphere would raise the total mana cost to .
338414: Goblin Electromancer.text_posted:
See Return to Ravnica FAQ: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/faq/rtr

YES this works with Overload (alternate cost), just like it would with flashback, or miracle.
YES this works with Replicate (additional cost) but NOT in the way you would expect. Replicate, like Kicker, Buyback, and Entwine, is an additional cost added on top of the normal cost. This means that no matter how many times you Replicate a spell, Electromancer only shaves [1] off the total cost. This seems meaningless at first glance, because it's only a discount of [1], but multiple Electromancers stack.

Say for example you control two Electromancers and cast [autocard]Pyromatics[/autocard], Replicating it once. The cost increase of Replicate is applied first, resulting in a cost of [2][R][R] - you are not casting two spells for [1][R] each, you are casting the one spell for [2][R][R]. The Electromancer's ability kicks in afterwards, reducing it by [2] (one for each Electromancer) meaning you pay a total of [R][R] for your replicated Pyromatics.

[autocard]Trinisphere[/autocard] complicates things further - it's applied even after the Electromancer's ability. In this hypothetical example, a Trinisphere would raise the total mana cost to [1][R][R].

338414: Goblin Electromancer.author: Worldferno
338414: Goblin Electromancer.text_parsed:
I would have to assume that the Electromancer, Djinn, Spike combo wouldn't work.

While copies of replicated spells have replicate themselves the copies replicate abilities cannot be triggered. That is because once it replicates it goes directly on the stack. *You aren't "playing" the copies.

So what you get is

Copy
Copy
Spike

Once the spike resolves you get the 2 mana replacing what you spent, but the other copies are already on the stack and can't be re-replicated.

If however you were playing in a multi-player match, had multiple copies of the spell in your hand, and 10 mana you COULD destroy 5 of your opponenets lands for each of the spikes in your hands since after the resolution of each stack you'd be floating enough mana to start another one.

338470: Magma Spray.author: leomistico
338470: Magma Spray.text_parsed:
If I had to choose between this and Pillar of Flame, I'd play this because instant speed is far better than sorcery. And if my deck needs this kind of effect, it means that what it want the most is the exile effect. If it weren't so, I would play Shock without any other thought. Or Lightning Bolt, for the matter. However, if dealing damage to player is something non-negotiable, then I would suggest you to look for Carbonize or Yamabushi's Flame, it depends from the format...

4/5

338473: Vigor Mortis.author: DarthParallax
338473: Vigor Mortis.text_parsed:
Not my favorite return-from-graveyard card, except that I LOVE the Flavor so much :D

I think that it's good for someone trying to strike a balance between 'Reanimation' and 'Playing for Fair and Fun'.

Frankly, there are so many faster ways to bring back certain guys that are so huge that +1/+1 makes little difference...but this will get you actually invited back to play next week, and those cards won't :)

338473: Vigor Mortis.author: DoragonShinzui
338473: Vigor Mortis.text_parsed:
There are far crazier cards to return creatures from your graveyard to play, but lets not talk about them. We don't compare every single draw spell to Ancestral Visions, we don't compare every return to play spell to Exhume, Animate Dead, and the like. Now that reanimation effects have been increased in price and stability somewhat, we can judge this for what it is: 4 mana to return a creature to play (fair), with an optional boost (good.)

This is a solid card, there should be no complaints.
